title: Strings & String Methods
description: Master text manipulation with Python string methods

content.text: Strings are sequences of characters (letters, numbers, symbols). Python has powerful built-in methods to work with text.
You can create strings with single or double quotes - they work the same:

content.code:
name1 = 'Alice'
name2 = "Bob"
sentence = "It's a nice day!"  # Use double quotes when text has apostrophes

print(name1)
print(name2)
print(sentence)
content.explanation: Single quotes and double quotes are interchangeable. Use double quotes when your text contains an apostrophe.

content.text: String concatenation means joining strings together with the + operator:

content.code:
first_name = "John"
last_name = "Doe"

full_name = first_name + " " + last_name
print(full_name)  # John Doe

# You can also repeat strings
print("Ha" * 3)  # HaHaHa
content.explanation: The + operator joins strings. The * operator repeats them.

content.text: Remember: You can't add strings and numbers directly. Use str() to convert numbers to strings first, or use f-strings!
Common string methods that change the case:

content.code:
text = "Hello World"

print(text.upper())      # HELLO WORLD
print(text.lower())      # hello world
print(text.title())      # Hello World
print(text.capitalize()) # Hello world
print(text.swapcase())   # hELLO wORLD
content.explanation: These methods return a new string with the case changed. They don't modify the original string.

content.code:
messy = "   Hello World!   "

print(messy.strip())       # "Hello World!" (removes spaces from both ends)
print(messy.lstrip())      # "Hello World!   " (removes from left)
print(messy.rstrip())      # "   Hello World!" (removes from right)

text = "Hello World"
print(text.replace("World", "Python"))  # "Hello Python"
content.explanation: strip() removes whitespace from the edges. replace() substitutes one substring for another.

content.code:
email = "user@example.com"

print(email.startswith("user"))     # True
print(email.endswith(".com"))       # True
print(email.count("e"))             # 3 (counts how many times)
print("@" in email)                  # True (checks if @ exists)
content.explanation: These methods help you check and search within strings. They're useful for validation!

content.code:
sentence = "Python is awesome"
words = sentence.split()  # Splits into a list
print(words)  # ['Python', 'is', 'awesome']

# Join them back
joined = " ".join(words)
print(joined)  # "Python is awesome"

# Split by a specific character
date = "2024-11-01"
parts = date.split("-")
print(parts)  # ['2024', '11', '01']
content.explanation: split() breaks a string into a list. join() combines a list into a string.

content.text: String slicing lets you extract parts of a string:

content.code:
text = "Python"

print(text[0])      # P (first character, index 0)
print(text[5])      # n (last character)
print(text[-1])     # n (negative index counts from end)
print(text[0:3])    # Pyt (characters 0, 1, 2)
print(text[2:])     # thon (from index 2 to end)
print(text[:4])     # Pyth (from start to index 4)
content.explanation: Use [start:end] to slice strings. Negative indexes count from the end. Remember: the end index is not included!

content.text: Strings are immutable - you can't change them in place. Methods like upper() and replace() return NEW strings.
The len() function tells you how many characters are in a string:

content.code:
name = "Alice"
password = "secret123"

print(len(name))      # 5
print(len(password))  # 9

if len(password) < 8:
    print("Password too short!")
else:
    print("Password length OK")
content.explanation: len() counts all characters including spaces. This is useful for validation!

content.prompt: Take the string 'hello world' and: 1) Convert it to title case, 2) Replace 'world' with 'Python', 3) Print the result.
content.solution:
text = "hello world"

# Convert to title case and replace
result = text.title().replace("World", "Python")
print(result)  # Hello Python
content.hint: Use .title() first, then .replace(). You can chain methods together!

content.text: Excellent! You now know how to manipulate strings like a pro. Next, we'll learn about making decisions with if/else statements!
